results.title: Judge Dredd for ZX Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, manual and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: Judge Dredd [computer game]. Judge Dredd is a single player action platformer. Players move Dredd to locations of crime as they appear on the sector map and select the crime they wish to pass judgement on. Once a crime has been selected, Dredd is dropped into a side scrolling platformer where both perps and civilians roam. Each crime is given an appropriate response level of Halt, Warn and Kill, though it is up to player discretion to change the response level. Depending on the response level is the action Dredd can perform, either shouting halt, firing warning shots or firing real bullets. Dredd can select a type of bullet from normal, armour piercing, incendiary, ricochet, high explosive and heat seeking.

results.title: Emulation of Decisive Battles of the American Civil War Vol 1 for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
Decisive Battles of the American Civil War, Vol. 1 lets you take the place of commanding generals in six battles of the American Civil War: first Bull Run, Shiloh, second Bull Run, Antietam, Fredericksburg, and Chancellorsville. In that role, players not only issue orders but take actions such as sleeping and determining their level of personal participation in the battle. The result is a fast-paced simulation (one hour per turn) of important moments in Civil War history. Victory is determined by a tally of casualties and controlled objectives. Two players may face-off in hot-seat mode, or a single player may face the computer or just observe the computer controlling both sides.

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1988 by Strategic Studies Group

results.title: Emulation of Operation Tiger Force for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
Operation Tigerforce is a single player action game set in a hostile warzone. Using the joystick, the player moves and shoots at both mobile and stationary enemies from a top-down perspective. Most enemies take several shots to defeat and will add to the player’s overall score. Getting hit by enemy bullets or touching an enemy will cost the player a life. The player is initally given two extra lives. Losing both will restart the game. There is a lengthy initial load time.
Original game created for Commodore 64 by Matthew Hall and released into the public domain circa 1985. More info on Matt Hall’s games can be found at: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/bedroom-coders-matthew-hall-15-commodore-64-games-rescued-from-decaying-cassettes/

results.title: America's Cup Challenge for Amstrad
results.creator_credit: Armchair Entertainment, US Gold Pty Ltd and Micro Forte Studios
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and manual in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
America’s Cup Challenge is a one to two player competitive sports simulation. The included manual contains a lot of information about the America’s Cup including yachting terminology, race legs, wind angles, sails and weather conditions. The player controls the crew of a racing yacht using the joystick, chosing the type of sail at the start of the race and then switching between three different modes, helmsman, sails selection and winching. As Helmsman, players control the yacht’s direction. Sail selection allows players to move the angle of the sail’s boom and the level of use of the spinnaker or genoa. The manual advises the use of a good quality robust joystick.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/arnies-americas-cup-challenge/
Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Micro Forté Pty. Ltd. for Commodore 64, published by Electronic Arts (USA) and U.S. Gold (Europe) in 1986.

results.title: Emulation of Bedlam for Spectrum 128 & +2
results.brief_description:
Bedlam is a top down vertical shooting scroller in a futuristic sci fi setting for one or two players simultaneously. Players pilot a vehicle shooting and dodging aliens and fighting boss ships.

Original game developed by Beam Software for Spectrum 128k & +2, Published in 1985 by Go! Media

results.title: Emulation of Castle of Terror for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
A single-player adventure game where the player is given a quest by an old man at the local tavern to rescue his daughter from the clutches of the local Count (a vampire), who resides in the nearby castle. Throughout the game, the player gathers items, which can then be manipulated to solve various puzzles.

Original game developed by Beam Software for Commodore 64, Published in 1984 by Melbourne House.

results.title: Rock & Wrestle for Commodore 64/128
results.creator_credit: Firebird Software, Melbourne House and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and paper booklet in a plastic cassette case..
results.brief_description:
Rock’n Wrestle (known as Bop’n Wrestle in the US) was one of the first games to have 3D movement through space. The game allowed for single or dual player modes, using the joystick or the keyboard supporting twenty-four wrestling manoeuvres. You could inflict pile drivers, arm-twists and body slams on your opponent. You play as blonde hero, Gorgeous Greg, named for the game’s creator, Gregg Barnett. Each of your ten opponents in the ring has a different personality and a distinctive wrestling style. Energy bars, which get depleted as you exert yourself, monitor your ‘lives’. A round is won when one of the wrestlers is pinned to the floor for three seconds. The next round offers opponents who are tougher than the last.
In addition to the use of characters moving through 3D space, Rock ‘n Wrestle offered a highly innovative set of context based moves. This meant that if a player lifts up another player it would unlocks a set of moves , or if you threw a player against the ropes it unlocks a suitable set of moves to capitalise on their rebound. This game is believed to be the first wrestling game for the home computer. Beam Software later had to turn down an approach by World Wresting Federation (WWF), as they were working on a Sergeant Slaughter title, missing out on being part of the huge, ongoing WWF video games franchise.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/rockn-wrestle-bobn-wrestle/
Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Beam Software for Commodore 64, published in 1985 by Melbourne House and Erbe Software S.A

results.title: The Muncher for ZX Spectrum 128
results.creator_credit: Rob Howard, Beam Software, Gremlin Graphics Software and Zero Wait
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, badge and manual in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: The Muncher [computer game]. The Muncher is a single player side scrolling action game. Players control a rampaging monster destroying buildings by climbing on them, breathing fire and jumping on people and cars while attempting to avoid getting shot at by people with guns. The game ends when the monster’s health has been depleted by being attacked.

results.title: Emulation of The Muncher for ZX Spectrum 128
results.brief_description:
The Muncher is a single player side scrolling action game. Players control a rampaging monster destroying buildings by climbing on them, breathing fire and jumping on people and cars while attempting to avoid getting shot at by people with guns. The game ends when the monster’s health has been depleted by being attacked.

Original game developed by Zero Wait and Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48/128, Published in 1988 by Gremlin Graphics Software
